ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Covered a significant amount of diverse literary and artistic production within the time frame proposed by the course.

This course allowed for deeper understanding of the correlation between of Russian political reality and the world of cinatograohy and literature as well as the degree to which mass media was used to control the population.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A lot of very interesting material, and Professor Clark knows so much! Very interesting and engaging discussions.

There was a lack of respect for the professor by some students in the class (ex: speaking over the professor, interrupting the professor, etc. etc). This was distracting and not conducive to productive discussion - the professor is absolutely amazing and her knowledge was often not available because of the lack of respect shown her and the other students. Perhaps in the future this behavior should be privately noted to the students so as not to take away from others' learning.

Every class included an analytical evaluation and discussion of assigned reading and film, which was an excellent source of gaining deeper understanding of the events that transpired at a certain period of time and how they affected the world of cinematography, literature and art in Russia.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! It's a unique opportunity to read and watch very recent cultural production form Russia, and professor Clark always knows so much relevant information, it is a huge pleasure and privilege to be in the class with her. I would highly recommend to anyone, Russian major or not!

Yes. The period covered is absolutely necessary and the selection of texts is very useful as the professor does not choose commonly taught texts/films. She exposes the students to relatively new material and this is integral to knowledge of the cannon.
It is a great course, and I would recommend it to anyone interested in Russian culture.
I would recommend Dr. Clark's class to anyone who is interested in Russian film, art and history.
Yes, it is truly and honor to be taught by Professor Clark.
